articles.title: Docker Desktop Accelerates Innovation with Faster Release Cadence

articles.title: Ask HN: How to Learn to Build Agentic AI Systems (Like Claude Code)
articles.description:
Hello folks,

Iâ€™m trying to learn how one can build agentic AI systems similar to Claude Code, and eventually adapt that knowledge toward domain-specific use cases (e.g., â€œClaude Code for healthcare, finance, education, etc.â€).

For those of you whoâ€™ve studied or built these kinds of systems, Iâ€™d love to hear your recommendations on:

â€¢ Foundational learning: What books, courses, or papers provide the best grounding for understanding LLM-based systems and their decision-making?

â€¢ Architectural patterns: What design patterns are worth studying for things like context management, memory, reasoning, and orchestration?

â€¢ Build vs. deploy: How do you think about building internal systems vs. packaging/distributing them as APIs, SDKs, or products?

â€¢ Open source projects: Which ones are most valuable to study for internals (decision making, evals, context engineering, tool use, etc.)?

â€¢ Evals and observability: What tools or products help evaluate quality, measure system behavior, and observe performance in real-world use?

â€¢ Models: Which models are best suited for â€œthinkingâ€ (reasoning, planning, decomposing problems) vs. â€œdoingâ€ (execution, coding, retrieval)?

â€¢ Learning path: How would you approach going from theory â†’ prototype â†’ production-quality system?

My goal is to discover high-quality resources that one can truly spend time learning from and building withâ€”through iteration and practiceâ€”while also sharing what I learn so others on the same path can benefit.

Thanks in advance for sharing your experiences and guidance!

articles.title: Ask HN: What are the best Google alternatives?
articles.description:
I am currently in the worst customer support situation I have ever been in with the Google Store. I ordered a gift for a friend, but Google sent me the wrong item. Google Support has acknowledged the wrong item was sent but in 3 days of back-and-forth communication, they have refused to refund me or ship a replacement. Both items are under $200.

If it were any other company, I would feel justified going to my credit card company and disputing the charge. However, I understand that if I initiate a chargeback, Google could terminate my account, so they have all the leverage in this interaction. I fully rely on my Google account for phone service (Pixel phone with Fi), email service (Gmail), documents/spreadsheets, photos, maps, and likely other items that are not coming to mind.

This event has made me realize that I've put too much of my life in one provider, and I need to switch. What alternatives does HN use for various Google services?

articles.title: Show HN: A more usable Docusign
articles.description:
Let me start off with a disclaimer.

I'm aware that there's like a gazillion e-signing products that exist in this space â€” including some half decent self-hosted options too. And yes I agree that the success of incumbents such as Docusign come primarily from distribution rather than making a superb product.

But hear me out. Few enterprise tools are as universally disliked as DocuSign: 1,050 Trustpilot reviews, 1.5 stars. To me, that signals two things: (1) a burning problem, and (2) an incumbent thatâ€™s barely tolerable.

My "vision" for my current project, Formable, is to eventually create something akin to a Figma/Linear/Canva â€” late to market, but disruptive through usability and fresh design. One example: our fields arenâ€™t static checkboxes. You can draw any shape/size, then apply logic with natural language (e.g. â€œmust be a valid US stateâ€).

Iâ€™m launching the free MVP now, with a waitlist for a much more advanced pro version. Iâ€™d love to gather some constructive feedback: what would make you actually love a paperwork tool?
